messages.content: You are an academic image analysis expert. Your task is to provide detailed descriptions of academic figures, diagrams, charts, or images. Describe what the figure shows, its potential purpose in an academic paper, and any key data or trends visible. The description should be concise and to the point, and should not exceed 100 words.
Please provide a detailed description of this academic figure.<image>

This diagram illustrates a biomedical or pharmaceutical analytical workflow. It shows a circular process beginning with sample collection, followed by laboratory analysis (represented by the flask icon), data processing/analysis (computer icon), and reporting/interpretation of results (document icon). The workflow includes integration with a database system and appears to demonstrate how analytical data moves through a quality-controlled scientific process. Arrows indicate the directional flow of information through each stage, suggesting an integrated analytical methodology likely used in research or clinical diagnostics.
You are a helpful academic expert, who is specialized in generating a paper poster, from given contents and figures.

Below is the figures with descriptions in the paper:
<figures>

<figure_0>
This figure shows a progression of computational models with increasing complexity (M=0.1 through M=1.0). It likely represents molecular simulations or protein aggregation patterns, with each model displaying different spatial arrangements of particle clusters. The color scale indicates some physical property (possibly energy or density). The visualization demonstrates how parameter M affects structural organization, with simpler patterns on the left evolving to more complex, heterogeneous structures on the right. This type of figure would typically appear in biophysics or computational chemistry literature to illustrate model sensitivity to a control parameter.
</figure_0>

<figure_1>
This figure shows three molecular visualizations (panels A-B-C) of what appears to be protein structures with color-coded elements representing different properties. Each panel displays a complex 3D molecular structure with color gradients indicating likely energetic or interaction characteristics. Small inset diagrams show the overall protein conformation. The color scales at the bottom suggest these are computational analyses of protein stability or binding interactions, potentially displaying mutation effects or structural variations. This visualization would be used in structural biology or protein engineering research to compare conformational states.
</figure_1>

<figure_2>
This figure depicts the secondary structure of a ribozyme or RNA molecule, showing its complex three-dimensional folding. The main image presents a detailed molecular structure with helical regions (labeled H73-H93) and various structural features including the L1 stalk, CP (central protuberance), and P-loops. Key functional elements like the 5-way junction and exit pore are highlighted in teal. The smaller diagram on the right provides a schematic representation of the RNA's base region. This visualization likely illustrates the architectural organization of a functional RNA, possibly ribosomal RNA, to demonstrate its catalytic or structural domains in biochemical literature.
</figure_2>

<figure_3>
This figure illustrates the structural components of ribosomal subunits in molecular detail. The left panel shows the large subunit featuring the peptidyl transferase center (PTC), L3 stalk, and L7/12 stalk with highlighted RNA bases in red. The middle panel depicts the small subunit with its platform, head, body regions, and functional elements like hinges and the decoding center. The right panel provides a classification of helical stacking patterns (basal/apical) and lists nucleotide positions for various structural elements (trunks, branches). This diagram likely serves to map key functional regions involved in protein synthesis and ribosomal mechanics.
</figure_3>

<figure_4>
This figure displays three molecular reconstructions of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) trunk segments labeled H27-H38, H41-H45, and H76-H79. Each segment shows the spatial arrangement of RNA helices, with red coloring highlighting specific structural features against a tan/beige backbone scaffold. The diagram likely serves to illustrate comparative structural biology of ribosomal components, showing how these helical segments organize and branch within the ribosome architecture. This visualization would be useful in academic literature examining ribosomal structure-function relationships or evolutionary conservation of rRNA structural domains.
</figure_4>

<figure_5>
This figure shows a sequence of computational simulations or visualizations displaying the evolution of a molecular or particle system across different timesteps or parameters (M=0.1 through M=1.0). The color-coding represents different properties (likely energy or density values) according to the rainbow scale shown at bottom right. Each image demonstrates increasing complexity or phase transition as the parameter value increases. This visualization likely appears in biophysics, statistical mechanics, or computational chemistry literature to demonstrate clustering behavior, aggregation phenomena, or phase transitions in complex systems.
</figure_5>

<figure_6>
The figure shows three molecular models (A, B, C) of porphyrin structures with different metal coordination centers, likely from research on biomimetic systems. Each panel displays a color-coded structural representation with thermal ellipsoids indicating atomic displacement parameters. Small inset images in the bottom left of panels A and C show the complete molecular packing arrangement. The color gradients at the bottom represent thermal parameters, with different scales used across the models. This visualization likely compares structural variations in metalloporphyrin complexes for catalytic or spectroscopic analysis.
</figure_6>

<figure_7>
This figure shows the structural diagram of a ribosomal RNA molecule, likely depicting a complex ribozyme structure. The left side presents the 3D molecular structure with labeled helices (H73-H93), while the right side shows a simplified 2D schematic of the base region. Key structural elements are highlighted in red and labeled with identifiers (H74-H89), with functional regions marked in teal text (P-loop, 5-way junction). This visualization would be used in biochemistry or molecular biology literature to illustrate RNA secondary and tertiary structure relationships in ribosomal function.
</figure_7>

<figure_8>
This figure illustrates the structural components of ribosomal subunits. The left panel shows the large subunit with labeled features including the peptidyl transferase center (PTC), L7/12 stalk, and L1 stalk. The middle panel depicts the small subunit with its platform, head, body regions, and functional centers (decoding center, ratchet, hinges). The right panel provides a legend identifying specific ribosomal proteins and RNA helices (B1-B17) with their corresponding numbering. Color coding (red/blue) appears to distinguish different molecular components, likely representing RNA nucleotides or specific structural elements.
</figure_8>

<figure_9>
This figure displays three reconstructed neuronal trunk-branch structures labeled with different time periods (H37-H38, H41-H45, H76-H79). The image shows the 3D morphology of neuronal projections, with trunk segments highlighted in red and branch segments in beige/brown. This visualization likely demonstrates developmental changes or growth patterns in neuronal architecture across different time points. The figure appears to be from a neurodevelopmental or neuroanatomical study examining temporal dynamics of neural branching patterns or axonal growth trajectories.
</figure_9>

</figures>

<paper_content>
Historical  (ideographic)  and  non-historical  (nomothetic) 
studies  of  ribosomal  accretion  (evolutionary  growth) 
appear  to  arrive  at  diametrically  opposite  conclusions. 
Phylogenetic reconstruction of the history of ribosomal 
proteins and ribosomal RNA (rRNA) of the small (SSU) 
and  large  (LSU)  subunits  suggests  that  the  ribosome 
unfolded by gradual accretion from structures supporting 
RNA decoding and ribosomal mechanics [1-4] (Fig. 1). In 
contrast, predictions from extant features in a handful of 
structural models of LSU rRNA support its origin in the 
peptidyl transferase center (PTC) and protein biosynthesis 
[5,6]. The algorithmic nomothetic model assumes that the 
ancient ribosomal core evolved by a series of putative 
insertions of ‚Äòbranch‚Äô helices onto preexisting coaxially 
stacked ‚Äòtrunk‚Äô helices, which appeared to originate in the 
PTC [6]:
It  also  assumes  an  ‚Äòonion‚Äô  model  of  growth  that 
pervasively  builds  the  molecules  inside-out.  Here  we 
analyze coaxial helical stacking patterns and insertion data 
and Ô¨Ånd that the claim that the ribosome originated in 
structures supporting protein biosynthesis is unwarranted. 
Instead, the analysis reveals possible primordial episodes 
of  substructural  grafting  of  core  rRNA segments  that 
conÔ¨Årm the previously proposed importance of decoding 
and ribosomal mechanics [1-4].
Patterns of coaxial helical stacking in ribosomal RNA support a model of molecular growth that is 
incompatible with an origin of the ribosome in the peptidyl transferase center 
Derek Caetano-Anoll√©s1,2 and Gustavo Caetano-Anoll√©s1,3* 
1C.R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology, 2Molecular and Cell Biology, and 3Crop Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
Background 
Coaxial helical stacking patterns fail to support models of 
apical growth of a branching and expanding ribosomal core 
structure. Instead, patterns support: (i) outward and inward 
growth  compatible  with  an  origin  of  the  complex  in 
ribosomal mechanics, and (ii) molecular growth by fusion 
of  smaller  ribosomal  pieces.  Together  with  tight  co-
evolution  of  ribosomal  RNA and  proteins  [4],  results 
challenge the ‚ÄòRNA world‚Äô dogma and prompt integration 
of  phylogenetic  and  structure-based  models  to  address 
evolutionary constraints acting on ribosomal structure.

Helical stacking in ribosomal RNA challenges the ‚ÄòRNA world‚Äô dogma
rRNA insertions are incompatible with an origin of 
the ribosome in protein biosynthesis. Analysis of a 
‚Äòfamily A‚Äô 3-way junction connecting a long helical coaxial 
branch  that  supports  the  PTC  to  a  trunk  (H76-H79) 
subtending  the  L1  stalk  and  its  translocation  functions 
reveals a branch-to-trunk insertion assignment that is in 
conÔ¨Çict with the PTC-centered accretion model. Instead, the 
insertion supports the ancestral origin of the crucial L1 
translocation structure (Fig. 2). Similarly, insertions linking 
terminal coaxial trunks that subtend the L7-12 stalk (H41-
H45) and structures of the central ribosomal protuberance 
(H37-H38)  to  a  7-way  junction  of  the  molecule  again 
question  the  early  origin  of  the  PTC.  These  trunks  are 
particularly important to both ribosomal translocation and 
energetics. Analysis of branch-to-trunk directionalities of 
insertions of domain V of LSU rRNA reveal that even the 
early evolution of the PTC does not follow the algorithmic 
model (Fig. 3).  
Global analysis of rRNA insertions reconcile the 
phylogenetic an algorithmic models of growth. 
Once assumptions of ‚Äòonion‚Äô layering are relaxed, models 
are reconciled and the origin of the ribosome is in structures 
supporting ribosomal mechanics, followed by the PTC and 
the exit channel (Fig. 4).
Roadblocks to an apical growth model of rRNA. 
The  analysis  of  all  coaxial  stacked  helices  reveals  that 
macromolecular accretion does not always occur via apical 
(outward)  growth  of  terminal  helices  (Fig.  5).  Instead, 
basipetal (inward) growth appears also common. The data 
suggests  a  dynamics  of  inward-outward  growth  that 
compromises, in the absence of phylogenetic information, 
the  construction  of  an  unequivocal  insertion-based 
algorithmic  model  of  accretion.  Instead,  coaxial  helical 
stacking patterns suggests scenarios of grafting of extensive 
rRNA  segments  or  accretion  from  a  primordial  core 
composed of multiple growing rRNA molecules.  
Fig. 2. Examples of branch-to-trunk directionalities disregarded by 
the algorithmic model [6]. Radial views of three coaxial helical stacks that subtend 
translocation functions. Putative primordial insertions of branches (colored tan) did not 
signiÔ¨Åcantly perturb trunk conformations (red).
Fig. 1. Phylogenomic model of ribosomal evolution. The  evolutionary 
timeline inferred directly from phylogenomic data shows that very early in evolution (nd 
< 0.3) rRNA helices interacted with r-proteins to form a processivity core, which later (nd 
= 0.3) served as center for coordinated and balanced ribonucleoprotein accretion.
Results 
Methods 
Conclusions 
Fig. 5. Roadblocks to apical growth. Patterns of coaxial helical stacking in rRNA deÔ¨Åne ‚Äòbranch-
to-trunk‚Äô directionalities that violate the ‚Äòonion‚Äô apical growth model [5,6]. Secondary structure models of 
SSU and LSU rRNA of the Escherichia coli ribosome are depicted with schematic representations of helical 
tracts (lines) and junctions (circles). Unambiguous coaxial helical stacking regions in 3-way and higher order 
junctions associated with putative sites of insertions [6] were indexed by examining structural models and 
conÔ¨Årmed by consulting descriptions of others (e.g. [7-9]). Coaxial helical stacking regions exhibiting inward 
(basipetal) and outward (apical) branch-to-trunk insertion directionalities are colored red (roadblocks) and 
blue(throughfares),  respectively.  When  travelling  from  the  base  (arrowhead)  to  the  periphery  of  the 
molecules, basipetal directionalities violate the ‚Äòonion‚Äô model. Stacked helices in B3, B4 and B9 subtend 
fundamental structures supporting translocation mechanics of the large subunit and stacked helices B11 
subtend half of the PTC. Patterns of coaxial helical stacking falsify an origin of the ribosome in the PTC [12]. 
Analysis of coaxial helical stacking present in SSU and 
LSU rRNA was guided by careful annotations of coaxial 
helical  stacking  regions  that  are  present  in  ribosomal 
junctions  of  3D  rRNA  models  [7-9].  Fig.  2  shows 
examples of trunks deÔ¨Åned by coaxial helical stacking.
Fig. 4. Reconciling models of LSU rRNA evolution. A.  Insertion-based  algorithmic  model 
that  accounts  for  A-minor  interactions  and  excludes  ancestrality  of  translocation  functions  [6].  B. 
Phylogenomic-based evolutionary model that is agnostic about mechanisms of ribosomal growth [4]. C. 
Revised  insertion-based  model  accounting  for  branch-to-trunk  insertion  directionalities  and  A-minor 
interactions that relaxes the ad hoc hypothesis of ‚Äòonion‚Äô growth. The evolutionary ages (nd) or phases are 
traced by color on individual helical segments deÔ¨Åned by the structural model of Escherichia coli (PDB 
entry 3R8S) and represented as secondary structures. 
Fig. 3. Analysis of domain V of LSU rRNA and the 5-way junction supporting the 
PTC. Coaxially stacked trunks are colored red in 3D structures and cartoons of secondary structure models. 
They cannot be explained by the algorithmic model.  Even the P-site of the PTC (helices H74 and H89) 
imposes a inward branch-to-trunk directionality that cannot leave an insertion Ô¨Ångerprint record.

Helical Stacking Patterns in Ribosomal RNA Challenge the 'RNA World' Dogma and the Peptidyl Transferase Origin of the Ribosome
Derek Caetano-Anoll√©s and Gustavo Caetano-Anoll√©s*
C.R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology, Molecular and Cell Biology, and Crop Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
Introduction

Historical (ideographic) and non-historical (nomothetic) studies of ribosomal evolution present opposing conclusions. Phylogenetic reconstructions suggest gradual accretion from structures supporting RNA decoding and ribosomal mechanics, while algorithmic models from structural data propose origin in the peptidyl transferase center (PTC). The algorithmic model assumes ancient ribosomal core evolution via insertions of 'branch' helices onto preexisting 'trunk' helices, with an 'onion' model of inside-out growth from the PTC.

Research Question

Do coaxial helical stacking patterns in ribosomal RNA support the claim that the ribosome originated in the PTC and protein biosynthesis, or do these patterns better align with models suggesting origins in structures supporting ribosomal mechanics and decoding?

Methods

We analyzed coaxial helical stacking present in small subunit (SSU) and large subunit (LSU) rRNA by examining structural models and consulting published descriptions. We identified unambiguous coaxial helical stacking regions in 3-way and higher order junctions associated with putative insertion sites, with special attention to branch-to-trunk directionalities that might confirm or challenge existing growth models.

Roadblocks to Apical Growth

Analysis of all coaxial stacked helices reveals that macromolecular accretion does not always proceed via apical (outward) growth of terminal helices. Instead, basipetal (inward) growth appears common, suggesting a dynamic of inward-outward growth that compromises construction of an unequivocal insertion-based algorithmic model. These patterns suggest scenarios of grafting extensive rRNA segments or accretion from a primordial core composed of multiple growing rRNA molecules.

rRNA Insertions Analysis

Examination of a 'family A' 3-way junction connecting a long helical coaxial branch supporting the PTC to a trunk (H76-H79) reveals branch-to-trunk insertion assignments conflicting with the PTC-centered model. Similar insertions linking terminal coaxial trunks that subtend the L7-12 stalk (H41-H45) and central protuberance (H37-H38) to a 7-way junction question the early origin of the PTC. Even within domain V of LSU rRNA, branch-to-trunk directionalities show that PTC evolution does not follow the algorithmic model.

Reconciliation of Models

Once 'onion' layering assumptions are relaxed, phylogenetic and algorithmic models can be reconciled. The emerging consensus suggests the ribosome originated in structures supporting ribosomal mechanics, followed by development of the PTC and exit channel. This integration of models respects both the phylogenomic data showing early formation of a processivity core and the structural insertion patterns when properly interpreted without preconceived directional constraints.

Conclusions

Coaxial helical stacking patterns fail to support models of apical growth of a branching and expanding ribosomal core structure from the PTC. Instead, patterns support: (i) outward and inward growth compatible with an origin in ribosomal mechanics, and (ii) molecular growth by fusion of smaller ribosomal pieces. Together with tight co-evolution of ribosomal RNA and proteins, results challenge the 'RNA world' dogma and prompt integration of phylogenetic and structure-based models to address evolutionary constraints acting on ribosomal structure.

International collaboration across multiple institutions including University of Bergen, Institut Pasteur, University of Tartu, and many other research centers worldwide
What is EDAM?

EDAM is an ontology of data analysis and data management in life sciences. Its structure is divided into 4 main sections:

  • Topic: Subject areas
  • Operation: Analysis processes
  • Data: Information objects
  • Format: Data representation

Identifier functions as a special kind of Data within this framework, creating a semantic knowledge graph where these entities interconnect through defined relationships.

Purpose and Benefits

EDAM enables researchers to annotate computational tools, workflows, data, and educational materials in a standardized way. This makes these resources:

  • Easier to find
  • Simpler to compare
  • More straightforward to choose
  • Seamless to integrate

EDAM supports open science by providing structured concepts for annotation of processed data, enhancing data findability, understandability, and comparability across different platforms and resources.

EDAM Updates in 2021

Key improvements this year include:

  • Easier contribution mechanisms for community involvement
  • Enhanced validation through improved continuous integration (CI)
  • Stronger community focus on inclusion and engagement with scientific experts, software engineers, and volunteers
  • Expanded collaboration network with new contributors joining the initiative
  • Application integration with platforms like Galaxy now visualizing tools panels sorted by EDAM categories
EDAM Tools

EDAM Browser: An ontology browser with user-focused features including aggregated search across resources like Bio.tools and TeSS, plus capability to suggest changes to EDAM (edamontology.github.io/edam-browser)

EDAM Popovers: Web-browser extension that displays details of EDAM concepts when selected on any website

EDAMmap: Text mining tool that extracts EDAM concepts from scientific articles (biit.cs.ut.ee/edammap)

EDAM as a Community

EDAM thrives as an open-source community with multiple engagement channels:

  • GitHub: github.com/edamontology/edamontology
  • Twitter: twitter.com/edamontology
  • Community chat: gitter.im/edamontology/edamontology

The project operates under an open license and actively welcomes new contributors from diverse backgrounds. The community includes researchers, developers, and volunteers worldwide, with support from ELIXIR Europe, Norway, and France.

Applications and Usage

EDAM is implemented across numerous bioinformatics resources and infrastructure projects including:

  • ELIXIR platforms (bio.tools, TeSS)
  • Galaxy Project
  • Debian Med
  • Expasy (Swiss Bioinformatics Resource Portal)
  • EMBL-EBI
  • Bioschemas
  • Common Workflow Language
  • FAIRsharing.org
  • BioSimulators

EDAM concepts can be browsed interactively at https://bioportal.bioontology.org/ontologies/EDAM and downloaded in various formats including OWL, TSV, and CSV.
